thread.title: Corporate-Bond Market Reopens as ADP, Home Depot Plan Deals
thread.title_full: Corporate-Bond Market Reopens as ADP, Home Depot Plan Deals - Bloomberg Business

author: Michelle Davis
title: Corporate-Bond Market Reopens as ADP, Home Depot Plan Deals
text:
Automatic Data Processing Inc. and Home Depot Inc. are among companies reopening the U.S. corporate-bond market after a 13-day drought in issuance.
ADP, a payroll processor, may sell $2 billion in debt in a two-part inaugural offering Tuesday to finance a previously announced share-buyback program, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. Home Depot, the home-improvement retailer, plans to issue $1.5 billion of notes in two-parts to pay for its acquisition of Interline Brands Inc. and to repurchase stock.
Bond sales by U.S. investment-grade companies are cranking up after global growth concerns stemming from news of an economic slowdown in China kept issuance at bay in the worst late-summer drought since 2005. Issuance may accelerate as borrowers seek to lock in financing for $420 billion of takeovers that are expected to be completed by the end of the year and investors look to reinvest cash.
“There was a lot in the pipeline -- the market seems in a better tone to place some of those,” said Dorian Garay, a New York-based money manager for an investment-grade debt fund at NN Investment Partners. The firm oversees $206 billion.
Other companies tapping debt markets include Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd., which is said to plan a bond offering in as many as three parts with the longest-dated portion maturing in 100 years, according to a person with knowledge of the deal. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and the financing arm of Deere & Co. may also issue benchmark-sized debt.
As companies pay off debt, Bank of America Corp.’s Hans Mikkelsen forecasts investors will have as much as $75 billion of cash to reinvest in the coming months.
ADP may issue bonds due in five years and a note maturing in 2025, said the person, who asked not to be identified because the information isn’t public. The company issued $805 million in convertible securities in 1992, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
The longest portion of Home Depot’s debt offering will be $1 billion in 10-year notes that may yield around 1.2 percentage points more than similar maturity Treasuries, said one of the people.
